div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE
No. 7,209] ALEXANDRIA, THURSDAY, JUNE 8, 1905. [SIX PAGES P.T. 1.
The Eastern Telegraph Company, Limited.
div.p:
This Company's system of submarine telegraph
cables is the most direct and quickest means of
communication from Egypt to Europe, North and
South America, East, South and West Africa,
India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.

To secure quick transmission, telegrams should
be marked Via Eastern.

For latest average time to London, see daily
bulletin in this paper.

STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo,
Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head
Office. London.

div.head: THE EASTERN TELEGRAPH
div.p: COMPANY LIMITED.

p.hi: This Company's system of submarine telegraph cables is the most direct and quickest means of coinmunication from Egypt to Europe, North and South America, East, South and West Africa, India, Australia, New Zealand, China and Japan.
To secure quick transmission, telegrams should be marked Via Eastern
For latest average time to London, see daily bulletin in this paper.
STATIONS IN EGYPT: Alexandria, Cairo, Suez, Port-Tewfik, Port-Saïd, Suakin. Head Office. London.

div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship’s accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company’s Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare is £ 9 to Brindisi.
The combined sea and special train fare has been reduced to £ 22.9.11 Port Said to London via Brindisi or via Mersailles.

During the Monsoon season the express steamer usually reaches Brindisi on Thursday afternoon, the special train starting at 8 p.m. and arriving in London at the very convenient hour of 4.56 p.m. on Saturday.
For all further information apply to the Company's Agents,
Messrs. THOS. COOK & SON (Egypt) Ltd. CAIRO.
GEORGE ROYLE, Esq. PORT-SAID.
Messrs. HABELDEN & Co. ALEXANDRIA.
F. G. DAVIDSON, Superintendent P. & O. S. N. Company in Egypt SUEZ.

div.head: Orient-Pacific Line of Royal Mail Steamers.
div.p: REDUCED SUMMER FARES FROM MAY TO OCTOBER INCLUSIVE.
OUTWARDS to AUSTRALIA.
R.M.S "Omrah" will leave Suez about June 16.
R.M.S "Orient" will leave Suez about June 30.
HOMEWARDS to NAPLES MARSEILLES, GIBRALTAR, PLYMOUTH, LONDON, TILBURY
R.M.S. "Ormuz" will leave Port Said about July 2
R.M.S. “Oroya" will leave Port Said about July 17
Egyptian Government Officials allowed a rebate of 15% off the above fares.

Return tickets no longer issued, but passengers paying full fare in one direction allowed abatement of 1/3 fare back if return voyage be within 4 months of arrival, or abatement of 20 o/o if return voyage be made within 8 months of arrival.

S.S. Cheshire 5,705 tons, leaves about July 6.
HOMEWARDS to MARSEILLES and LONDON. Departures from Port Said.
S.S. Lancashire 4,344 tons, leaves about June 12.

Agents Cairo: THOS. COOK & SON. Suez & Port Said : WM. STAPLEDON & SONS,

div.head: KHEDIVIAL MAIL LINE.

p.hi: FAST BRITISH PASSENGER STEAMERS
GREECE - TURKEY LINE.

div.p: Express Steamers leave Alexandria every Wednesday at 4 p.m. for PIRAEUS, SMYRNA, MITYLENE, and CONSTANTINOPLE, in connection with Orient Express train-de-luxe for Vienna, Paris, and London.

p.hi: PALESTINE - SYRIA LINE.

div.p: Fast steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 6 p.m., and Port Said every Sunday at 6 p.m., for JAFFA (for Jerusalem), CAIFFA (for Nazareth), BEYROUT (for Damascus), TRIPOLI, ALEXANDRETTA, MESSINA, continuing in alternate weeks to LARNACA and LIMASSOL (Cyprus).

p.hi: RED SEA LINE.

div.p: Steamers leave Suez fortnightly on Wednesday at 6 p.m. for JEDDAH, SUAKIN, MASSOWAH, HODBIDAH, and ADEN ; and in the intervening weeks for PORT SUDAN and SUAKIN direct. Calls will be made at TOR (for Mount Sinai) as required.
N.B.—Deck chairs provided for the use of passengers, excellent cuisine and table wine free.
Steamer plans may be seen and passages booked at the Company’s Agencies at Alexandria, Cairo, Port Said, and Suez, or at THOS. COOK & SON or other Tourist Agency.

div.head: The Moss S.S. Company, Ltd.
div.p: For LIVERPOOL calling at MALTA (Messrs. JAMES MOSS & Co. 31, James St, Liverpool, Managers.)

*Second class accommodation only, unless specially reserved.—Fares : Alexandria to Liverpool, 1st, £14 Single, £25 Return. 2nd, £9 Single, £15 Return.—To Malta, 1st, £5 Single, £9 Return, 2nd, £3 Single, £5 Return.—Return tickets available for six months.
S.S. Seti now on the berth, will sail on or about Monday, July 17, to be followed by S.S. Menes.
S.S Tabor for Havre via Malta to sail about Saturday l5th inst.
Through freight rates on cotton, etc., to Lancashire inland towns, Boston, New York and other U.S.A. towns, obtained on application. Cargo taken by special agreement only.

R. J. MOSS & Co., Alexandria, Agents.

RESIDENTS IN EGYPT proceeding to Europe for the summer are requested to apply to our offices for information respecting their Passages, where steamer plans may be consulted and Berths secured by all Lines of Steamers to all parts of the Globe; arrangements can also be made for the collection and forwarding of their baggage and clearance at port of arrival.

CIRCULAR NOTES issued payable at the current rate of exchange in all the principal cities of Europe. Cook’s Interpreters in uniform are present at the principal Railway stations and Landing-places in Europe to assist passengers holding their travelling tickets.

Large and splendidly appointed steamers belonging to the Co. leave Cairo thrice weekly, between November and March, for Luxor, Assouan and Wady-Halfa in connection with trains de luxe to Khartoum. Moderate fares.

Weekly Express Mail Service. Steamers leave Alexandria every Saturday at 4 p.m. arrive at Brindisi, Tuesday a.m. in time for express to Paris, London, Naples, Rome. Arrival Trieste Wednesday noon connecting with Vienna Express (Trieste-Ostende through carriage) and expresses to Italy and Germany.

div.head: British Chamber of Commerce.—
div.p: We would call the attention of persons interested in Egyptian trade to the work of the British Chamber of Commerce of Egypt, whose office in Alexandria gives information as to standings trade, &c., to its members, and whose monthly publication reviews our commerce. The annual subscription is 11 and all British traders should become members. Our London office, 36, New Broad- street E.C., acts as London agency to the Chamber.

A perfect food is Bovril—it nourishes, stimulates and reinvigorates. Bovril is of great value for all to whom strength and endurance are a vital necessity. Its regular use is a permanent protection against the dangers of fcolds, chills and diseases.

div.head: THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE.
div.p: SUBSCRIPTIONS.—Alexandria, Cairo, and the Interior of Egypt (including delivery in Alexandria or postage to subscriber’s address) P.T. 231½ per annum, P.T. 116 for six months, P.T. 80 for three months. To other countries in the Postal Union P.T. 273 (£2.16s.) per annum. Six months P.T. 136½ (£1.8s.), three months P.T. 92 (£0.19s.) N.B.—Subscriptions commence from the 1st or 16th of any month.

ADVERTISEMENTS.—P.T. 4 per line. Minimum charge P.T. 20. Births, Marriages, or Deaths, not exceeding three lines, P.T. 20. Every additional line P.T. 10. Notices in news column P.T. 20 per line. Contracts entered into for standing advertisements.
SUBSCRIPTIONS and ADVERTISEMENTS are due in advance. P.O. Orders and Cheques to be made payable to the Editor and Manager, Rowland Snelling, Alexandria.
London Offices : 36, New Broad-street. B.C.
THE EGYPTIAN GAZETTE can be obtained in London at our office, 36, New Broad Street, E.C., and also at Messrs. May & Williams 160, Piccadilly, W.
DEATH. MORGAN.- On the 7th inst., at Assiout, George Gray, the beloved son of George and Florence Morgan, aged 2 years.

THURSDAY, JUNE 8, 1905.

p.hi: FRANCE'S FOREIGN POLICY. The new Fronoh Minister for Foreign Affair will, we are informed, "uphold the Russian alliance, bąt will probably iosist on Russia guaranteeing that in fotore she will not take any action to jeopardise its utility, and will show herself more amenable to her ally's advice." These words are somewhat indefinite but they clearly show that Rassia's plight is a matter of serious preoccupation to her ally. France is traversing & real crisis. The late Baron Rothschild reckoned the amount of French capital sunk in Russia at eleven milliards of francs, that is to say, at more than twice the war indemnity paid by France to Germany. Now, however distasteful the alliance may be to the Republican spirit in the country, it is impossible for any Government to cut loose therefrom. Anything done politically wbich would weaken the hold of France upon the creditor, would be immediately hailed by the people as an aot of treachery. A Government that attempted it would inevitably fall, and perhaps the régime with it. Knowing that, and knowing, also, that if the war onds in the final humiliation of Russia, which is more than likely in the circumstances, the French people may whistle for their capital, and even for their interest, M, Rouvier's preoccupations may well be imagined. M. Deloassé endeavoured to stave off the evil day by supporting Russia to the utmost of his power, and by interpreting the neutrality question in a manner which, at least, did not embarrass the movements of Rodjestvensky. Apparently he thought by 80 doing that the Russian Admiral would regain the command of the sea. But he was deceived.

His successor evidently intends to adopt | plain speaking. That the French people feel deeply pained by recent events in St. Petersburg and elsewhere can hardly be doubted. They are a nation with a genius for civilisation. On the Continent of Europe it was they who performod the rough pioneer work of Democracy and they who struck the great omancipating
Individually and collectively they have been staggered by the superfluous ruthlessness of the Russian bureaucracy. It has wounded them alike in their consciences and in their
deepest political instincts. There is no country OBTI

in which during the late events the apolog. ists for absolutism have been so few and 50 tinorous. There is no country in which the denunciation of the Russian autocracy and its agents has been so spontaneous and irreprossible. The French have, indeed, felt in a special degree the ignominy of what has happened. They cannot quite acquit them selves, as the allies of Russian of all the responsibility, or at least of all the disgrace. They were never before so conscious of the gulf that separates them from the Russian Government. The realisation of this by the common sentiment of the French people is the immediate result of the St. Petersburg mas. sacre. It cannot, as some think, leave things as they were. It is bound, we are told, to have political results. And what those results will be is plainly stated. The weakening of the ties that bind Rassia and France in alliance is regarded as a probable, or even inevitable, consequence of the recent events and there appears to be a general expectation that the intense feeling of humiliation and repulsion with which France bas watched these events will loosen the corner-stone of her entire foreign polioy and create an atmosphere which will invalidate, if not dissolve, the Dual Alliance.

We cannot share this opinion, which seems to us to be based upon a very incomplete notion of what the Dual Alliance is and what it has accomplished, not only for France but for the peace of Earope. People have fallen into the habit of talking of it as a hopelessly one-sided compact. They have said that France has had to pay for it in gold, and that Russia has requited her with nothing but fine phrases. Gold has certainly passed, whether to the amount of two hundred, or four hundred, or
eight hundred millions sterling is a uninor and matter. Enough that the French have undoubt
edly subscribed handsomely to Russian loans 288) and invested with almost reckless confidence in six
Russian indastrial enterprises. But is it true
that fine phrases are the only or even the chief ber
reward the French outlay has met with? Is it not rather the case that France has some tangible benefits to show for her share in the
partnership 1 They might all be summed 1st up in a word, the word that Pitt used to

crystallise the one object of all others that Mi-| Great Britain aimed at in hunting down 2188, Napoleon, the word that the late Lord Salisbury 20. used as the goal of British policy in South :|Africa-security. France is secure, and not only
France, but the French Republic. The formation of the Dual Alliance removed once and for all the charge of political dowdiness that its
enemies, with a sure instinct for the foibles of and their countrymen, were continually bringing itor against the Republic. To be great, to bave a
position, they said, France must be monarchical. The alliance showed that Russia, and, following
Russia, all Europe, considered that the Republic ned

had come to stay, and had something worth having to offer by way of exchange. The moral effect of the alliance was worth at the time almost anything to the French. If people have at last got used to the idea of a Republic in
France, if the Republic has established itself the beyond doubt, the Dual Alliance must

largely be thanked for it. Internal peace must, therefore, be set down as one of the compensations derived from it by France. External peace it has yet more obviously guaranteed. There is, as things now are, no chance whatever of France being threatened and humiliated by any such movement as Bismarck is said to have meditated in 1875. The alliance removed the sense of helplessness ander which France was laboaring twenty years ago. These are two inestimable benefits derived by France from the alliance, and they are well understood by all close observers of Earopean affairs.

Nor is this all. France derives from the alliance with Russia advantages which no other Power conld undertake to provide. It is an excellent thing that France should now be on terms of cordial confidence with Italy and with ourselves. It is yet more excellent that after many years of anxiety, nervousness, and insecurity the Republic should now have entered the zone of hopefulness, and inspiriting baoyanoy. Bat it is doubtful whether Great Britain or Italy could possibly render to France one form of assistance of which she might some day be in vital need. It was until recently believed that that help could be given by Russia, and this was the belief ander which France entered the Dual Alliance. The question now is whether, in view of recent events in the Far East and in Russia, this determining consideration needs to be modified. Meantime it is evident that the Republic has gained by the Dual Alliance, both at home and abroad, and it is not by any means clear that the dissolution of the alliance would be & gain to France. She would be no; merely parting with an ally, she would be throwing into that ally's arms the very Power from whom she must always have the most to fear. We can only begin to gaage the preventive and deterrent efficacy of the Dual Alliance by imagining it at an end. Some thirty odd years ago Carlyle wrote : "That noble, patient, deep, and solid Germany should be at length welded into & nation and become Queen of the Continent, instead of vapouring, Vainglorious, gesticulating, quarrelsome, restless, and oversensitive France, seems to me the hopefullest public fact that has occurred in my time." Germany has become better known since then, and of the two nations we should not to-day say that it is France that is vainglorious, or restless, or quarrelsome. Those who expect the dissolution of the Dual Alliance should try and work out what its disappearance would mean to France, to Germany, to the present balance of power in Europe, and, therefore, to Great Britain,

div.head: RUSSIA AND PEACE.
div.p: As a result of a Council of Ministers held at Tsarskoe Sele, yesterday, instructions have been telegraphed today to the Russian Ambassadors at Washington and Paris that Russia is desirous of learning the Japanese peace conditions. (Reuter.)

Despite the prohibition of the authorities, the members of the Zemstvos sat the whole day. The speakers were unanimous in declaring that the nation itself must decide the question of peace, and reorganise the State. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE "SMOLENSK" AGAIN!
ANOTHER MARAUDING EXPLOIT.
div.p: The Russian auxiliary cruiser "Rien," formerly the "Smolensk," stopped the British steamer "Cilurmon" on the 2nd instant, 80 miles from Woosung, examoned her papers, threw overboard part of her cargo, and then escaped suspecting the approach of the Japanese. (Reuter.)

div.head: ORDERED FROM MANILA.
div.p: Admiral Enquist has been ordered to sail within 24 hours or disarm. (Havas.)

div.head: FRANCE'S FOREIGN POLICY.
M. ROUVIER'S PROGRAMME.
div.p: M. Rouvier will conduct the Ministry of Foreign Affairs till the questions pending are settled. This change will not affect the entente with Great Britain. M. Rouvier will also uphold the Russian alliance, but will probably insist on Russia guaranteeing that in future she will not take any action to jeapordise its utility, and will show herself more amenable to her ally's advise. (Reuter.)

div.head: THE MOROCCAN IMBROGLIO.
div.p: The comments of the newspapers attest the gravity of the imbroglio in Morocco. It is believed that M. Rouvier's first endeavour will be to find a compromise acceptable to Germany. (Reuter.)

div.head: KING ALFONSO IN LONDON.
MAKING AN EXCELLENT IMPRESSION.
div.p: In spite of the wretched weather King Alfonso is being greatly feted and is making an excellent impression by his gaiety and bonhommie. All official speeches on both sides are full of the friendliest expressions to the respective nations. King Alfonso lunched in full state at the Guild hall today. (Reuter.)

div.head: KHEDIVE LEAVES FOR PARIS.
div.p: The Khedive has left for Paris. (Havas.)
The match between Cambridge University and Gentlemen of Englan has been abandoned without a ball being bowled on account of rain. Sussex beat Lancashire by an innings and 215 runs.
The matches between Yorkshire and Australians, Northamptonshire and Leicestershire, and Somerset and Hampshire have been drawn. (Reuter.)

div.head: NORWAY AND SWEDEN.
div.p: The Norwegian Parliament has unanimously passed a resolution severing, the connection of Norway with Sweden, declaring that King Oscar bas ceased to be King of Norway, and conferring on the present Ministry the powers of government appertaining to the King. The address to King Oscar further declares that no ill-will is felt either to him or to Sweden, and asks his Majesty to co-operate in securing the selection of a young Prince of his House as King of Norway (Reuter.)
The Storthing has decided on the dissolution of the union with Sweden. It has asked King Oscar to authorise his son to become King of Norway (Havas.)
King Oscar has telegraphed to the Norwegian Premier protesting most emphatically against the action of the Government. (R.)

The action of the Norwegian Parliament in dissolving the union must either lead to war or to the acctptance of the situation by Sweden. The divergence of view is really of old standing, dating back almost to the earliest days of the union of the two kingdoms. That the possibility. of a conflict was foreseon from the first is evident from the declaration made by the first Sovereign of the united states, King Carl XIII., who in 1815 pointed out in a Royal "proposition" that “when two nations of their own accord submit to the same Government it is incumbent with the greatest care to avoid differences of any kind arising in regard to their relation to the common Regent. Otherwise the union sooner or later. will be broken, and either the one people will soon subjugate the other or their violent disruption will sow the seed of bitter dissension which may for centuries keep them apart.” In the case of Norway and Sweden no precaution which the circumstances of the time could suggest appears to have been neglected. The separate existence of the two States, united by the golden link of the Crown, was fully recognised, but the wisest of statesmen cannot possibly foresee and provide for every development which the future may have in store. In all their internal relations the maximum of freedom was secured, to each State to progress along its own lines. Each has its own legislature, its own laws, its own system of finance, its own methods of raising revenue and regulating its trade relations, both with its partner and with the rest of the world. Each, again, has its own Army and its own Navy, and it is only in their relations with other States that any serious difficulty has manifested itself. The Norwegians, with their Monarchical traditions, were content that the conduct of foreign relations should remain the prerogative of the Sovereign, but, when, in 1885, a change in the Swedish Constitution brought the conduot of foreign affairs more directly under the control of the Swedish Ministry, it is not surprising that a people so tenacious of their rights, and so ready to discern an attack on their status as a Sovereign State, should take alarm at what, viewed from the standpoint of Sweden, may have seemed a legitimate development of the constitutional principle of Ministerial responsibility. The controversy which twenty years ago assumed definite shape has been allowed to drag on ever since, while each successive attempt to arrive at a settlement has resulted in failura and has left behind it an increasing bitterness of feeling until now the aged King Oscar is face to face with the terrible dilemma of either having to begin what would be virtually a civil war or acqaiesce in the disrgption of Scandinavia. It is unfortunate that this contretemps should have occurred on the eve of the marriage of Prinod Gustavus, which is to take place in London this day week.

p.hi: The Princesses Hussein Bey Kamel were among the passengers who left for Constanti nople yesterday by the 8.8. "Prince Abbas.?
The Sirdar and Miralai Stack Bey are or pected to arrive at Alexandris on Friday | night and to embark on the following day for Trieste.
Colonel Lewis Pasha, who has been staying at San Stefano Hotel for some time past, is leaving for Port Said on Saturday to catch the P. &0. 8.S. "Osiris."
Mr. Chataway, Administrator of the Alex andria Municipality, is going on three months' leave of absence on Saturday, July 7, by the Austrian Lloyd steamer.
Mr. Salomon Sasson has presented £5 to the British Benevolent Society of Alexandria op. the occasion of thé marriage of his son, Mr. Moses Sasson, with Miss Mario Tilche.
Dootore Théodore Fletoridis and Abbas Holmy have been anthorised to follow their profession in Egypt
The Plague.—Yesterday's balletin records a recovery at Toukh.
Tax P. & 0. mail steamer "Ogiris" arrived at Alexandria from Port Said this morning and went into drydock.
STRAY AND OWNERLESS Dogs found in Old Cairo to-morrow night and at daybreak on Saturday will be poisoned by the police.
Fight ON ATE Quays. – Two different gings of coal beavers had a fight on the coal. quays. yesterday, and two were seriously injured. 28 of the ring-leaders were arrested.
Cairo-ALEXANDRIA TELEPHONĖ. –The Railway Administration has decided to double the telepkone line between Cairo and Alexandria, and to join it with Tantab and Kaft Zayat.
Delta Draht Railways. — The Ministry of Public Works has decided to authorise the Egyptian Delta Light Railway Company to construct a railway line from Kanayat to Sahraght, in the Menoufieh.
GATTi's Circus Troups opens at the Pyramids Theatre, near the G.P.O., this evening, and there shoald be & bumper house to welcome them back. Several new artistes have joined the company.

Suez Canal.—9 vessels passed through the Canal on the 5th inst., 3 of which were British, i Turkish, 3 German, 2 Dutcb. The day's receipts were frs. 268,023.05, making the total from the 1st inst. fra 4,910,924.82.

SANITARY DEPARTMENT.-Aziz Effendi Kerba, Francis Effendi Elias, and Mohamed Effendi Askar, who obtained their diplomas as veterinary surgeons at the recent examination, have beon appointed vaterinary inspectors of the 4th class.

EGYPTIAN TRUST AND INVESTMENT.-Application has been made to the London Stock Exchange Committee to appoint a special settling day in Egyptian Trust and Invest-| ment, Limited—200,000 shares of £1 each, 58. paid, Nos. 1 to 200,000.

National Bank of Egypt.–To-day, the 8th inst., the preferential rights of shareholders to an allotment of the 50,000 new shares now being offered will expire, all applications, together with share certificates and amount payable on application, having to be lodged on or before to-day.
DR. ELMER LANSING.

It is with great regret that we record the death of Dr. Elmer Lansing, which occurred at the German Hospital, Cairo, on Tuesday evenFing. Dr. Lansing was well-known in his profession as a specialist in eye diseases, and his loss will be keenly felt by his colleagues and by his numerous friends. He was one of the oldest of the American residents in Egypt and for many years lived at Helouan, where his geniality and kindness gained for him a large circle of friends and admirers. The faneral service was held at the Mortuary Chapel of the German Hospital at 4 o'clock yesterday afterDoon and was attended by the greater part of the American colony in Cairo. Dr. Lansing leaves behind him a widow and daughter, who have spent their lives in Cairo and Helouan with him, and two song, who are at college in Amprica. We extend our heart-felt sympathy and sincere condolences to the bereaved family.
MRS. PONZETTA. - We regret to announce the death, which took place at her residence at Sohutz yesterday, of Mrs. Mary Popzetta. The funeral will leave Schutz Station. Magnin's House, at 3p.m. to-day.
SAN. STEFANO CASINO.

The following is the programme of the grand boncert to be given on Sunday next, commencing at 10 a, m, by the Bracale orohestra. 1 Marche Heroique a 2 Rapsodie Bretonnne Saint-Saeng 3 Symphonie Landliche Hochzeit-Goldmark
(a) Im Garten, Andante (b) Tanz, Finale Ouverture Tannhauser-Wagner.
Our readers will note that No. 9 and 8, Rapsodie Bretonns and Sympbonie Goldmark, are executed for the first time at Alexandria.
ESBEKIEH GARDENS.
By kind permission of Major C. J. L Davidson, commanding, and officers and Royal Inniskilling Fusiliers, the Band will play the followng selection of music in Esbekieh Gardens co-morrow at 9 p.m.

div.head: ALEXANDRIA HARBOUR.

p.hi: THE NEW PASS.
The following official notice has been iannel
The dredging for a new pass is about t be commenced.
The cutting will be between the Hydrogra pher shoal and North shoal out to the deep water.

Tall poles, which will bave fixed white lights suspended from them at night, hav been placed in position to mark the sides o the pass, and mariners are cautioned wher entering or leaving the Boghaz Pasa not to confose these poles and lights wit! the side beacons or leading lights of tha
pass.

div.p: WOO

p.hi: The lights will only be of low power. :
The approximate positions of the pole are :N. E: front polo Max low light X. 1. E, 356 yarda

div.p: N. 16. 2. W N. L. back polo For high light 8. 17. . 145 . · & W. .

p.hi: X, 88. X. 160 The poles are liablo to slight alteration in posi
Bearings are magnetic and given from thé poles. -- INTENDED ALTERATION OF LIGHTS.

The fixed white light on the Boghaz gas beacon, and the fixed red light on the end of the breakwater, are about to be altered to occultating lights. | The change will be effected in 'about three months, when further potices will be issued..
THE GHIRGEH SCANDAL.

Oar Assiont Correspondent, telegraphing I yesterday afternoon, states that the acquittal of the accused in the Gbirgeh scandal case has caused general satisfaction. He adds that when the judgment was delivered cheers were given in Court.
The vernacular Press expresses it's satisfaction with the judgment.
NEW EGYPTIAN COMPANY.

L'UNION PONCIERE D'EGYPTE. The Union Foncière d'Egypte has been formed with a capital of £500,000, divided into 100,000 shares of £5 saob, for the purpose of undertaking land operatidos of every description. The capital of the dpmpany has been wholly subscribed as follows The AngloForeign Banking Company, Limited, 4,000; P. P. Rodocanachi & Co., 2,000 ; Société Marseillaise de Crédit Indastriel et Commercial et de Dépôts, 6,000 ; Zafiropoulo & Zarifi, 4,000; J.. Aghion e figlio, 28,000 ; C. M. Salvago & Co., 28,000.; C. G. Zeryadachi & fils, 28,000. There are also 5,000 - founders' shares, which have been distributed as follows The AngloForeign Banking Co. Ltd., 200 ; P. P. Rodo canachi & Co., 200, Société Marseillaise de Crédit Iridustriel et Commercial et de Dépôts, 400 ; Mafiropoulo & Zarif, 400 ; J. Aghion et figlio, 1,284 ; C. M. Salvago & Co., 1,258; C. G. Zervadachi & fils, 1,258.
TANTAH MUNICIPALITY.

The inhabitants of Tantah bave long been desirous of having a Municipality similar to those established at Mansourah and Medinet el-Fayoom, and in response to a petition to the authorities, authorisation has now been granted to form a mized Comiission.

The decree, which appears in yesterday's "Journal Officiel," says that "in view of the favorable results .obtained at Mansourah and Medinet el:Fayoum, by the system accordirg to which the inhabitants are called upon to co-operate in the improvement of their town by voluntary taxes... and in view of the request of the inhabitants of Tantah to obtain a municipal regime for their town similar to that in Mansourah and. in Medinet al. Fayoum... the inhabitants of Tantab are authorised to establish optional (facultatives) taxes on the merchandise exported or imported in their town, in order to meet the cost T of improvements in their town, the construo|tion of drains, lighting, drinking water supply,
filling up of marshes or other bygienio works, paving or upkoop of publio streets, and other i works of a similar character."
The decree embodies the constitution of the Commission.
GREECE AND EGYPT.

It is reported from Athens that the negotia tions between the Egyptian and Hellenio Governments relative to the new commercial treaty have not come to a satisfactory conolasion. The existing trasty will remain in force until March 31, 1906, i.o., for an extra period of tan months.
FAYOUM LIGHT RAILWAY.

div.p: (FROM OUR CORRESPONDENT ).

Medinet al Payoum, Wednesday, I hear Mr. Davison has been sucomaful in the Mixed Tribunals in getting judgment with costs against the Fayoum Railway Company, and I trust he will not be long before he obtains another position, and one where he vill receive better treatment than he from his late employers. Mr. Davison hag during his residence here gained the good-will and esteem of the whole province for his straightforwardness, and both Mrs. Davison and he will be missed by many friends. This, I I think, is the second caso decided against this ! company within a fow worke.

div.head: GRAND HOTEL BONNARD, ALEXANDRIA.
div.p: 2s. PER DAY. WINE INCLUDED.

div.head: NOTES FROM SUAKIN.

p.hi: SUDAN GOVERNMENT RAILWAYS.

div.p: (From our Correspondent).

p.hi: Suakin, May 81.
The railway line has now reached Sinkat, where it is intended to start the Kursals line, for which a big credit has now been granted by the Egyptian Treasuty.

Sinkat is a very healthy and cool station and it is proposed to preot a very fine Government Hospital there, on the lines of a hang togiom. All officers and Government officialswill be sent there from all parts of the Sudan As convalescents to recruit their health, instead of, as now, being sent to the Cairo military and civil hospitals. .

It is rumoured that both lines from the Atbara and Saakin will be joined by the end of September, 1905, but that it will not be open to traffic until the early part of 1907, in order to give the whole line time to consolidate, so as secure it against heavy rains and floods. All the bridges, numbering hundreds, will be completed by that time.
The British steamer Tabaristan” arrived here "from England on the 26th inst. with a special consignment of coal and other railway. material for the Sadan Government Railways.

The Khedivial mail steamer." Missir arrived here from Suez on the 29th inst. and landed the following new railway officials who arg to be employed on the Suakin. Atbara line : Mr. Albert Cree (of Alexandria), to take over the appointment of Traffic Inspector ; Mr. Hewson, Assistant Loco. Sape. rintendent, and Mr. Warn, engineer in charge of condensors. Mr. Warn has brought his wife and children with him.

It is with great regret that I have to record the death of Mulazim Awal Abdilmeghid Effendi Hilmy, Sadan Government Railways, which took place yesterday at his residence in Saakin, from appendioitis. He had been for some time in the Civil Hospital and was operated on by Doctorg, Orispin and Fahmy. Abdilmeghid Effendi was a member of the board of officers of the Sådan Railways here, and spoke English fluently. He was a promising young officer, and very much esteemed by all his friends. He leaves a widow and children hore. to 'mourn his loss. His funeral took place early this morning, and was attended by a large number of officers from the railways, the Moudirieb, and the 6th Battalion Egyptian Army. The firing party was farnished by the 6th Battalion.
It is also with regret that I have to report the serious illness- of Mr. Smart, chief storekeeper, Suakin-Atbara line, who has been laid up with high fever since the 28th inst.
ARRIVALS.
Per S.S. "China," arrived Port Said Taesday; from London : Mrs. M. Jarvis ; from Marspilles : Major W. F. Hessey, Mr. C. Modwill, Mr. A. McCallam, Mr. H. Mousareff, Mr. J. W. Gardner.
Per 8.8. Osiris” arrived Port Said yesterday from Brindisi : Mr. H. C. Crabbe, Signor G. Tosca, Mr. Machaky.
DEPARTURES.
Le paquebot "Prince Abbas" de la Cie Khádiviale, parti hier après-midi pour le Pirée, Smyrne, Métélin, Dardanelles et Constantinople, avait à bord :

Poannatioos, Kyrinco Joannon, P. Patrikios, Hag Aly offendi, J. Malunos, Mme Malanog, Fre derio Reiser, Klie Caragiorgio, Ugo Handosman, Carmen Pomares, B. p.hi: STEAMER MOVEMENTS.
The Westoott 8.8. "Avoca" arrived to day tom Antwerp, London, and Malta with a eneral onrgo.
The Messageries Maritimes 8.8. "Portugal" rrived at Marseilles from Alorandria yunter Lay morning
The B.S. "Grecian Prino," from Mancha er, lett Malta on Wednesday and ideo hoto a Sunday nearts with passengers and more!

div.head: SPORT AND PLAY.

p.hi: KHEDIVAL YACHT CLUB.
REGATTA. The following in the result of yesterday's regatta :

Agamy 8.18.55 4.41.19 Mr. Ravelly Leman
3.12.18 4.44.56 Mr. de Planta Tiéral Mina 3.06.10 4.45.35 Capt. Borg Coot 3.05.28 4.45.45 Mr. Preston Jenny
3.03.13 4.47.20 Mr. T. M.Clare Banshee 3.16.19 4.51.06 Mr. S. Dorling May 3 .0525 5.02.12 Sagh. Herbert
CLASS II. | 1 Jessica 3.20.22 4.58.03 Grafton Boy 12 Gumrook 3.31.42 5.00.07 Chitty Bøy 3 Akraba ( 3.25.65 5.00.22 Sagb. Phillips
Ironie V 3.90.18 5.00.38 P. Girard Cattelaya" 3.25.52 5.00.57 D. K. Raid $t. George 3.83.19 5.01.23 Major Feotham Masri
3.84.11 5.01.45 Mr. Fransis. Calypso 3.41.13 5.03.10 Mr. Werner Tantah 3:39.17 5,04.88 J. Bally. Shamrock · 8.30.25 gave up Lieut. Bassett The wind was moderate from the N.N.W.

The Sula II." of the "Commodore"in Clau I. "Walked” clean away from all the other boatų and came in an easy first, and therefore carried off Chitty Bey's cop. This boat will mae next week under the name of "Sans Paroille" u she has changed owners, and now belongs to Mr. H. de Teokadi. The "May" brought up the rear, and it is a pity that in doing so she should have forced her right-of-way with the winning boats of the other class n thereby she herself gained nothing and imporilled their chances.

In Class II the "Calypso" unfortunately crossed the line too soon and had to deturn and recross, thereby losing over a minute ; moreover she is not plaoed until the question of her forcing "Sala. II!" at the "black and white” buoy is decided by the sailing com.

After the races the 'Gumrook," with a "tais” in charge, anfortunately ran into the "Ironie” and Mr. P. Girard, vesy narrowly. escaped being injured by her bowsprit, bąt got off with a few bruises only

The finish of Class II. was a very pretty one, when seven boats crossed the lino within 14 minutes, thus showing a handicap which it. will be difficult to improve | Next week the regatta will start half an hoar later than the present starting time.
ORICKET.

B. T. C. v. A MUSTAPHA XI. Played on Tuesday on the A. C. C. ground. This match was won easily by the E T. C. by an innings and 45 runs. Mr.. G. T. Malan played a dashing and lively innings of 61 for the B. T. 0. The first woket put on 96 zane. Scores : - :
